title: Decoding Aircraft (ADS-B)
content:
# Decoding Aircraft with ADS-B

ADS-B (Automatic Dependent Surveillance–Broadcast) lets you track every aircraft within hundreds of miles using your SDR.

## How It Works

Aircraft broadcast their GPS position, altitude, speed, and callsign on **1090 MHz** once per second. These transmissions are unencrypted and freely receivable.

## The Data

Each ADS-B message contains:
- **ICAO address** — unique aircraft identifier (e.g., 406A3B)
- **Callsign** — flight number (e.g., BAW256)
- **Position** — latitude and longitude
- **Altitude** — in feet (barometric or GPS)
- **Velocity** — ground speed and heading
- **Squawk** — transponder code

## Emergency Squawks

| Code | Meaning |
|------|--------|
| 7700 | Emergency (Mayday) |
| 7600 | Radio failure |
| 7500 | Hijack |

## Antenna Tips

ADS-B works best with a vertical antenna tuned for 1090 MHz. A quarter-wave ground plane has elements of 6.9cm. Mount it as high as possible — even a window mount helps dramatically.

steps.title: Set Up the Receiver
steps.content: Tune your SDR to 1090 MHz with 2 MHz sample rate. The ADS-B decoder handles the rest — no demodulator needed.

steps.title: Watch the Map
steps.content: Switch to Map View. Aircraft appear as icons with callsigns. Click one to see its full data — altitude, speed, heading, and track history.

steps.title: Optimise Your Setup
steps.content: The number of aircraft you see depends on antenna quality and placement. A proper ADS-B antenna at rooftop height can see 200+ miles in every direction.

quiz.question: What frequency does ADS-B use?
quiz.explanation: ADS-B operates on 1090 MHz, in the L-band.

quiz.question: What does squawk 7700 mean?
quiz.explanation: 7700 is the international emergency squawk code, indicating a mayday situation.
